title: Ministers set for crunch talks with the steel industry as job fears grow
text:
Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom is to be asked on Tuesday to step in and save a Tata Steel plant in Newport, South Wales

Ministers are set for crunch talks with the steel industry this week amid fears for thousands of jobs in the sector.

Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom is to be asked on Tuesday to step in and save a Tata Steel plant in Newport, South Wales, due for closure by the end of the year with the loss of 400 jobs.

And on Monday Nadhim Zahawi, the new steel Minister, is due to meet Tata and other firms at an industry gathering led by UK Steel and the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Steel and Metal Related Industries.

The talks come as fears rise for British Steel and its 5,000 workers after the firm fell into administration in May.

The Insolvency Service had entered exclusive talks with Ataer, the Turkish army’s pension fund. But last week it was forced to reopen discussions with other parties – thought to include the UK’s Liberty Steel and China’s Jingye – after failing to agree a deal with Ataer.

Liberty will be among the firms present at tomorrow’s event involving Zahawi.

On Tuesday, it is understood that union leaders are meeting Leadsom to put forward a plan to save Tata’s Orb plant in Newport.

Consultancy firm Syndex, working on behalf of the workforce, is said to have devised a plan for the plant to produce new kinds of steel products for use in electric cars.

Union bosses are expected to ask Leadsom to commit £30million to the scheme.
